pr_title: [homekit] bugfix 7491 / add support for merging several updates to one command

timeline.message:
add support for merging several updates to one command

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

timeline.bodyText: If the class is not annotated @NonNullByDefault why do you need @Nullable here?
timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: yeah, i tried to make it @NonNullByDefault but i had to make too many exceptions and suppress warnings so i decided to remove NoNullByDefault but forgot nullable
replies.author: yfre

timeline.bodyText: I'm not 100% sure that is the correct behaviour. Is 100% always send along ON? or can it be 50% and ON? The reason I ask is that I have a lot of KNX dimmers (in fact they are DALI, but connected over KNX). If I select the light in the HomeKit app (state was OFF) and set it to 50% via the slider it always turns on at 100%. IMO this is because ON is interpreted as 100% and overrides the brightness send before. So I think that ON should not be send but the actual brightness if both commands are available.
timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
did some tests:


Dimmer Off and i click on "device icon": home app sends "On" and Brightness = 100% independent on brightness which was before.


Dimmer On and i change brightness, e.g. from 50% to 60%, home app sends "On" and selected brightness (e.g. 60%). this was not covered by PR. will add commit


Dimmer is off and i open "Control" and select brightness, e.g. 60%,  home apps sends "On" and selected brightness.


to me - we need only to suppress brightness=100% in the first case.
do we need to suppress "On" in the 2)?
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: Well, at least in my setup „ON“ always results in 100% on KNX dimmers. So I would prefer to suppress the ON instead of the brightness. However, for ZigBee devices this would lead to 100% even if the light was at 40% before and could resume that state.
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
ok. looks like we need to make configurable.
do i understand correctly we have 2 cases:

suppress "ON". so, never sends "ON" update only Brightness.
suppress 100% brightness (which typically comes with "ON" event)

anything missing ? do we need to suppress "OFF"?
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText:
The problem is that this would need to be configured on item level.
What is send along with OFF? 0%? For hue/deconz lights (not sure about zigbee) sending 0% would result in a light going to on after the next ON command but with brightness 0, so actually the light is still off.
In what situation would you want to suppress 100%? All my devices would work perfectly if we only send brightness. Obviously HomeKit wants to turn the light full on if it sends ON and 100%. Or is this a limitation of HAP-Java which generates two commands where HomeKit sends only ON?
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
we had this use case in some tickets/discussion - Dimmer could have  a soft launch on On, i.e. increasing brightness slowly to 100%.
HomeKit home app is sending always "On" and "brightness", both with one request, e.g. setting brightness with to 72
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText:
Of course I don't know all devices, but at least all of my device also use some sort of transition time when the brightness changes (i.e. 100% and ON are equal). Also the change from say 10% to 90% is not instantaneous but is slower or faster depending on the configured time for that.
At least for KNX, DMX, deconz and hue lights this works. I agree that the "double command" is wrong in most cases, but I don't know of any device that would fail or behave wrong in case only the brightness is send.
Maybe the following would be a good scheme:
ON / 100 % -> ON
ON / 1-99% -> 1-99%
OFF / 0% -> OFF
Would that cover everything?
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
yes, probably your case will cover most of the setups.
but let's make configurable on the item level.
i add following 4 modes (better names are welcome)

none: nothing is filtered. this is default
filterOn: all "on" events are filtered. only brightness is sent.
filterBrightness100: brightness 100 is filtered when "ON" is sent. everything else with no changes. i.e. "on" along with brightness. this would support "soft launch"
filterOnExceptBrightness100: your proposal. brightness <100% -> "ON" event filtered, brightness = 100% -> only ON is sent

code committed. please take a look.
once we are ok with the logic and naming, i will update README
replies.author: yfre

timeline.author: J-N-K

timeline.bodyText:
My comment regarding the naming is also valid here. It would be better to have somthing like
final Item item = taggedItem.getItem();
timeline.author: J-N-K
J-N-K
J-N-K
J-N-K

timeline.bodyText: For null safety I would prefer to instantiate on object creation I don't think we'll have so many items that an empty HashMap creates a significant burden on the whole system
timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
my reasoning was -  i have around 80 items and 0 dimmer and 0 hue devices, so, it will create 80 empty hashMap without having usage for it.
hm.. but actually, on other side, it will also create 80 HomekitOHItemProxy without real need for it.
so, if we go for optimisation to probably at much earlier point - dont create HomekitOHItemProxy in first place which makes the logic even more complex.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: yes, probably better readable.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.message:
incorporate J-N-K feedback, adapt the logic for dimmer

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

thanks. for some reasons i used to have loggers static and im typing "static" automatically.
i will fix that one.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: all if statements should have brackets
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: This doesn't look like a safe cast
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: You should adjust this logic to take into account that DimmerItem only cares about the BRIGHTNESS_COMMAND and ON_COMMAND and a ColorItem only cares about the HUE_COMMAND and SATURATION_COMMAND.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: ColorItem can handle "On" and "Brightness" as well as it extends the DimmerItem. so, probably i only need to exclude the combination "DimmerItem + hue or/and saturation"
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: Ah, you are right about the ColorItem extending DimmerItem.
replies.author: cpmeister

timeline.author: cpmeister
cpmeister

replies.bodyText: it should make much difference in that case. we would interrupt "sendCommand" which we will re-run directly after cancelation. but you are right, false is probably the saver option.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.bodyText: Please add @NonNullByDefault
timeline.author: cpmeister

+/**

+ * See the NOTICE file(s) distributed with this work for additional
+ * information.

+package org.openhab.io.homekit.internal;
+
+import java.util.HashMap;
+import java.util.Map;
+import java.util.Optional;
+
+/**
+ * Dimmer commands are handled differently by different devices.
+ * Some devices expect only the brightness updates, some other expect brightness as well as "On/Off" commands.
+ * This enum describes different modes of dimmer handling in the context of HomeKit binding.
+ *
+ * Following modes are supported:
+ * DIMMER_MODE_NORMAL - no filtering. The commands will be send to device as received from HomeKit.
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON - ON events are filtered out. only OFF and brightness information are sent
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_BRIGHTNESS_100 - only Brightness=100% is filtered out. everything else unchanged. This allows
+ * custom logic for soft launch in devices.
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON_EXCEPT_BRIGHTNESS_100 - ON events are filter out in all cases except of Brightness = 100%.
+ *
+ * @author Eugen Freiter - Initial contribution
+ */
+public enum HomekitDimmerMode {

replies.bodyText: right. forgot that one. fixed

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+/**
+ * Copyright (c) 2010-2020 Contributors to the openHAB project
+ *
+ * See the NOTICE file(s) distributed with this work for additional
+ * information.
+ *
+ * This program and the accompanying materials are made available under the
+ * terms of the Eclipse Public License 2.0 which is available at
+ * http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-2.0
+ *
+ * SPDX-License-Identifier: EPL-2.0
+ */
+package org.openhab.io.homekit.internal;
+
+import java.util.HashMap;
+import java.util.Map;
+import java.util.Optional;
+import org.eclipse.jdt.annotation.NonNullByDefault;
+
+/**
+ * Dimmer commands are handled differently by different devices.
+ * Some devices expect only the brightness updates, some other expect brightness as well as "On/Off" commands.
+ * This enum describes different modes of dimmer handling in the context of HomeKit binding.
+ *
+ * Following modes are supported:
+ * DIMMER_MODE_NORMAL - no filtering. The commands will be send to device as received from HomeKit.
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON - ON events are filtered out. only OFF and brightness information are sent
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_BRIGHTNESS_100 - only Brightness=100% is filtered out. everything else unchanged. This allows
+ * custom logic for soft launch in devices.
+ * DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON_EXCEPT_BRIGHTNESS_100 - ON events are filter out in all cases except of Brightness = 100%.
+ *
+ * @author Eugen Freiter - Initial contribution
+ */
+
+@NonNullByDefault
+public enum HomekitDimmerMode {
+    DIMMER_MODE_NORMAL("normal"),
+    DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON("filterOn"),
+    DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_BRIGHTNESS_100("filterBrightness100"),
+    DIMMER_MODE_FILTER_ON_EXCEPT_BRIGHTNESS_100("filterOnExceptBrightness100");
+
+    private static final Map<String, HomekitDimmerMode> TAG_MAP = new HashMap<>();
+
+    static {
+        for (HomekitDimmerMode type : HomekitDimmerMode.values()) {
+            TAG_MAP.put(type.tag.toUpperCase(), type);
+        }
+    }

replies.bodyText: cool. one-liner
replies.author: yfre
